commands.title: Global Warming: Understanding the Crisis and Finding Solutions
commands.subtitle: A Call to Action

slides.title: What is Global Warming?
slides.content: Global warming refers to the long-term heating of Earth's climate system observed since the pre-industrial period (between 1850 and 1900) due to human activities, primarily fossil fuel burning, which increases heat-trapping greenhouse gas levels in Earth's atmosphere.

elements.description: Simple rectangular shape behind the title for emphasis.

slides.title: The Greenhouse Effect
slides.content: The greenhouse effect is a natural process that warms the Earth's surface. When the Sun's energy reaches the Earth's atmosphere, some of it is reflected back to space and the rest is absorbed and re-radiated by greenhouse gases. Absorbed energy warms the atmosphere and the surface of the Earth. Human activities are increasing the concentration of these gases, leading to enhanced warming.

elements.description: Simple diagram illustrating the greenhouse effect (Sun -> Earth -> Atmosphere -> Space).

slides.title: Causes of Global Warming
slides.content: The primary cause is the burning of fossil fuels (coal, oil, and natural gas), which releases large amounts of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. Deforestation also contributes, as trees absorb carbon dioxide.

elements.description: Simple bullet point list highlighting key causes.

slides.title: Evidence of Global Warming
slides.content: Rising global temperatures, melting glaciers and ice sheets, rising sea levels, changes in precipitation patterns, and more frequent and intense extreme weather events are all indicators of global warming.

elements.description: A simple line separating the title from the content.

slides.title: Impacts on the Environment
slides.content: Global warming leads to habitat loss, species extinction, ocean acidification, coral bleaching, and disruptions to ecosystems. Changes in temperature and precipitation patterns can affect agriculture and water resources.

elements.description: A simple arrow pointing downwards to symbolize negative impacts.

slides.title: Impacts on Human Health
slides.content: Increased heat waves, air pollution, spread of infectious diseases, and food and water scarcity are all potential health consequences of global warming.

elements.description: A simple medical symbol to represent health impacts.

slides.title: Mitigation Strategies
slides.content: Transitioning to renewable energy sources (solar, wind, hydro), improving energy efficiency, reducing deforestation, and developing carbon capture technologies are crucial mitigation strategies.

elements.description: Simple icons representing renewable energy sources.

slides.title: Adaptation Strategies
slides.content: Building seawalls, developing drought-resistant crops, improving water management, and strengthening public health systems are important adaptation measures to cope with the impacts of climate change.

elements.description: Simple icons representing adaptation measures (e.g., water drop, building).

slides.title: International Agreements
slides.content: The Paris Agreement is a landmark international accord aimed at limiting global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and pursuing efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

elements.description: A simple globe icon to represent international agreements.

slides.title: Call to Action
slides.content: We all have a role to play in addressing global warming. Support policies that promote clean energy, reduce your carbon footprint, and advocate for a sustainable future.

elements.description: A simple upward pointing arrow to symbolize positive action.
